This movie exists. This phrase is a total cop-out, I know. People tend to say this when they don‚Äôt want to confront the movie at all or feel frustrated by it or bored or confused; I think I‚Äôm the latter. This movie thought it was saying something and it didn‚Äôt. It‚Äôs like trying to make filet minion out of a Lunchable: you don‚Äôt have the ingredients. It was never going to coalesce and so the end result is the most jumbled tonal mish-mash I‚Äôve ever seen.

Our hero is a pretty typical late 80‚Äôs guy named Harry (Anthony Edwards). You probably recognize Edwards as one of the nerds from ‚ÄúRevenge of the Nerds‚Äù. You will not recognize him in this get up as ‚ÄúGoose‚Äù from ‚ÄúTop Gun‚Äù.

Our heroine is Julie (Mare Winningham) who I guess did something to piss off the hairdresser because they cursed her with what can only be described as a mullet. Time has not looked back fondly upon this haircut. Harry only squeaks by without being heckled by me, the cruel audience, because he is extremely unremarkable in every conceivable way.

I don‚Äôt think the narrative realizes that Harry and Julie are the most annoying people on planet Earth. Over the course of like 3 hours at the La Brea Tar Pits (which, I‚Äôm not sure if you know this, smell like absolute shit due to being full of dead garbage), they madly in love with each other, as seen through some scenes where they flirt obnoxiously by quipping jokes about fossils to other people‚Äôs children (?). Their weird scenes being so heavily focused around children lead me to believe that Harry was a museum employee and she was a teacher on a field trip, but no, he‚Äôs a trombone player and she‚Äôs a waitress. There‚Äôs absolutely no reason for these two to be talking to random stranger‚Äôs kids and using them as means by which they demonstrate how cute they are to each other. It gave me the same weird douche chills I used to get watching people become twin flame soulmates via public forum chatrooms just by posting rapidly back and forth at each other back in 2008.

Harry is literally, immediately introduced to Julie‚Äôs family which is apparently composed entirely of her grandparents who haven‚Äôt spoken to each other in 15 years. The scene in which we meet them is about 30 seconds long and exists only to introduce this plot point which never really amounts to anything and its inclusion only makes the day-long courtship feel like it‚Äôs been going on for much, much longer. The scale of time in this movie prior to the phone call the kicks off the actual plot is completely incomprehensible. Is it intentional? Are we supposed to feel like they‚Äôve known each other forever even though it‚Äôs been like 6 hours? After the phone call, the movie proceeds in real time, which is legitimately interesting and works pretty well. But everything before that feels like it takes place out of time.

They agree to meet for a date, but a bird with a cigarette burns the power lines to Harry‚Äôs hotel room (??) so he wakes up 3 hours late. He rushes to the diner they were supposed to meet at in the hopes that Julie will return if he makes enough desperate calls from the pay phone outside (but she‚Äôs completely zonked out from a Valium, she‚Äôs not on this planet). One thing about this scene that‚Äôs totally inconsequential in the grand scheme of the plot is that in order to indicate how late he‚Äôs slept, the TV is blaring the national anthem and playing that filler they used to play late at night. Remember when TV used to end?? There was a point during the day where there was no more TV. Never mind I don‚Äôt care about this anymore. Harry just hit a palm tree and like 5 rats fell out of it onto his car. I only care about this now.

The movie now does something terrible, which is that it really, truly believes that it is a strong character driven story and thus introduces a plethora of characters all at once, all of which are either cliche (the crazy homeless man, the career driven 80‚Äôs business woman) or exaggerated caricatures of people we might know in real life but exacerbated to such a degree that it feels like Harry is ordering food from the comfort of a diner in Toontown and not L. A. It is odd that the movie bothers to introduce these characters and flesh them out to what little degree it does and then toss them away after the diner scene entirely. But this is a movie in which a cigarette smoking bird causes a power outage.

Harry calls Julie and instead of getting a call back from her, the voice on the other end of the payphone is a panic-stricken young man in a missile silo babbling about how nuclear war is on our doorstep.
